name: APJ Abdul Kalam
quote: Dream is not that which you see while sleeping; it is something that does not let you sleep.
bio:
Born on October 15, 1931, in Rameswaram, Tamil Nadu, to a poor Tamil Muslim family. 
Sold newspapers as a child to support his family but excelled in studies.Graduated in Physics (1954) and aerospace engineering (1960), overcoming financial hurdles.Joined ISRO (1969): Played a pivotal role in India’s first Satellite Launch Vehicle (SLV-III).As Chief of DRDO, led the development of:Agni (ballistic missile) and Prithvi (tactical missile).Pokhran-II nuclear tests (1998), establishing India as a nuclear power. 
Earned the nickname 'Missile Man of India'. Inspired millions with his humility and dedication to science.Authored books like 'Wings of Fire', motivating youth worldwide.Advocated for peaceful nuclear technology and rural development. Died on July 27, 2015, while delivering a lecture—symbolizing his passion for education.Awards: Bharat Ratna (1997), Hoover Medal (2008), and honorary doctorates globally.Remembered for his quote: 'Dream, dream, dream. Dreams transform into thoughts, and thoughts result in action'.

name: Steve Jobs
bio: Born February 24, 1955, in San Francisco, adopted by Paul and Clara Jobs. Dropped out of Reed College (1972) but audited calligraphy classes—later inspiring Mac’s typography.Co-founded Apple in his parents’ garage (1976) with Steve Wozniak. Apple Revolution (1976-1985): Apple I (1976): Hand-built computer that launched the company.  Macintosh (1984): First mass-market PC with a graphical interface. Fired from Apple in 1985 after internal conflicts. In 2004: Diagnosed with pancreatic cancer; delayed treatment for 9 months. NeXT & Pixar (1985-1996): Founded NeXT Computer (high-end workstations). Bought Pixar (1986), producing Toy Story (1995)—first CGI animated film. Returned as CEO (1997) and saved Apple from bankruptcy. Made technology intuitive, artistic, and personal.  Created the 'Apple Ecosystem' (hardware, software, services).  Inspired startups worldwide with his focus on design + functionality.  Died October 5, 2011, from cancer complications.
book: Steve Jobs (Walter Isaacson), The Innovators (Walter Isaacson)

name: Nelson Mandela
quote: Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world.
bio: Born July 18, 1918, in Mvezo, South Africa. Member of the Thembu royal family. Studied law and co-founded South Africa’s first Black law firm (1952). Joined the African National Congress (ANC) in 1944 to fight apartheid.  Anti-Apartheid Movement (1950s-1964): Led peaceful protests and the Defiance Campaign (1952).  Co-founded Umkhonto we Sizwe (1961), ANC’s armed wing, after non-violent options were crushed.  Arrested in 1962, sentenced to life imprisonment in 1964 (Rivonia Trial). 27 Years in Prison (1964-1990): Incarcerated in Robben Island under brutal conditions. Became a global symbol of resistance, with campaigns demanding his release.  Ending Apartheid (1990-1994):  Freed in 1990 after international pressure.  Negotiated with President F.W. de Klerk to end apartheid.  Awarded the Nobel Peace Prize (1993) with de Klerk.  Presidency (1994-1999):  Elected as South Africa’s first Black president (1994).  Promoted reconciliation (Truth and Reconciliation Commission) over vengeance. Focused on dismantling systemic racism and poverty. Inspired civil rights movements worldwide. Proved forgiveness could heal nations (e.g., embraced former jailers). Raised awareness about HIV/AIDS after presidency.  Died December 5, 2013, aged 95.
book: Long Walk to Freedom (Mandela’s autobiography), The Prison Letters of Nelson Mandela

name: Elon Musk
quote: When something is important enough, you do it even if the odds are not in your favor.
bio: Born June 28, 1971, in Pretoria, South Africa. Taught himself programming at age 10. Moved to Canada at 17 to avoid mandatory service in South African military. Earned degrees in Physics and Economics from the University of Pennsylvania. Co-founded Zip2 (1995), sold to Compaq for $307 million. Founded X.com (1999) which became PayPal, sold to eBay for $1.5 billion. Founded SpaceX in 2002 to make space travel affordable. Became Tesla's largest investor in 2004, later CEO. Revolutionized electric cars with Tesla Roadster (2008) and Model S (2012). Proposed Hyperloop (2013) and founded The Boring Company (2016). Acquired Twitter (2022), renamed X (2023). First privately-funded company (SpaceX) to send astronauts to ISS (2020). Currently working on Neuralink (brain-computer interfaces) and AI through xAI.
book: Elon Musk: Tesla, SpaceX, and the Quest for a Fantastic Future (Ashlee Vance), Liftoff: Elon Musk and the Desperate Early Days That Launched SpaceX (Eric Berger)

name: Srinivasa Ramanujan
quote: An equation for me has no meaning unless it expresses a thought of God.
bio: Born December 22, 1887, in Erode, Tamil Nadu, India. Showed exceptional mathematical talent from childhood, mastering trigonometry at age 12. Failed college exams multiple times due to focusing only on mathematics. Worked as a clerk in Madras while independently developing revolutionary mathematical theories. Sent letters to British mathematicians containing his original theorems. Invited to Cambridge University by G.H. Hardy in 1914, recognizing his genius. Published groundbreaking work on number theory, infinite series, and continued fractions. Developed the Hardy-Ramanujan number 1729 (smallest number expressible as sum of two cubes in two different ways). Became first Indian Fellow of the Royal Society in 1918 and Trinity College Cambridge Fellow in 1919. Returned to India in 1919 due to deteriorating health. Made substantial contributions to mathematical analysis, number theory, and mock theta functions. Died April 26, 1920, at age 32, leaving behind notebooks filled with unpublished theorems that continue to inspire mathematicians.
book: The Man Who Knew Infinity: A Life of the Genius Ramanujan (Robert Kanigel), Ramanujan: Letters and Commentary (Bruce C. Berndt), Notebooks of Srinivasa Ramanujan (2 Volumes)

name: Albert Einstein
quote: Imagination is more important than knowledge. Knowledge is limited. Imagination encircles the world.
bio: Born March 14, 1879, in Ulm, Germany. Showed early fascination with mathematics and physics despite initial speech difficulties. Worked as a patent clerk in Bern, Switzerland, while developing his groundbreaking theories. Published the Annus Mirabilis papers in 1905, including the theory of special relativity and E=mc² equation. Awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect. Developed the general theory of relativity in 1915, revolutionizing understanding of gravity, space, and time. Fled Nazi Germany in 1933 and settled in the United States, joining Princeton University. Warned President Roosevelt about potential German nuclear weapons, leading to the Manhattan Project. Became a vocal advocate for civil rights, pacifism, and Zionism. Died April 18, 1955, in Princeton, New Jersey, leaving behind a transformed understanding of the physical universe.
book: Einstein: His Life and Universe (Walter Isaacson), The World As I See It (Albert Einstein), Relativity: The Special and General Theory (Albert Einstein)
